awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal:   High Resolution Spectroscopic Studies of Ionic Metal-Ligand Bonds
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms program supports the collaborative research projects of Professor Leah O'Brien at Southern Illinois University Edwardsville and Professor James O'Brien at the University of Missouri, St. Louis.  They investigate the spectroscopy of diatomic metal containing molecules that also contain nitrogen or halogen atoms (for example fluorine or chlorine). The work is enabling a deeper understanding of these molecules' chemical bonding and electronic structure. Participants record high resolution spectra in the visible and infrared wavelength region with light-absorption and/or emission spectroscopic methods. This project continues an inter-institutional collaboration of faculty and students at a primarily undergraduate institution and a major research university.  It enhances the research infrastructure at both Universities, and develops students and faculty with skills in contemporary spectroscopy and instrument development.  The project also contains an outreach program that allows talented high school students to participate in the research.

The O'Brien groups use intracavity laser absorption spectroscopy combined with high resolution Fourier transform detection (ILS-FTS).  The plasma discharge techniques to produce the molecules of interest employ radio frequency (RF) and direct current (DC) plasma generators as used in industry. The spectra are rotationally analyzed to obtain new and/or improved molecular constants (e.g., transition energy, rotational and vibrational constants, and angular momentum coupling constants). These constants are used to develop energy level diagrams and potential energy curves for molecules, which enable comparison of the experimental results with computational results for these small molecules. This work enhances our understanding of metal-ligand interactions, periodic trends in for metal-ligand binding, and provides insight on metal-catalyzed reactions.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported collaborative research on metal-containing diatomic and triatomic molecular radicals.  Our experiments involved creating radicals in a hollow cathode sputter source, recording spectra using an ultra-sensitive intracavity laser absorption (ILS) technique, and analyzing the spectra to produce molecular constants that describe the electronic structure of the molecules.  This work has applications in understanding metal-ligand interactions and provides insight on metal-catalyzed reactions.  Moreover, our new work on 5d metal sulfides provide gold-standard measurements of electronic transitions in these molecules that are used as benchmarks by theoreticians developing new models for electronic states.  For many of the species, the extreme relativistic effects of 5d metals dominate the electronic structure, and spectroscopic data on the metal halides, oxides and sulfides allow comparison with relativistic electronic structure calculations by theoreticians.

1.      Instrument Development.  Our original ILS equipment utilized a 2-m grating spectrometer for data collection, which produced spectra with an effective spectral resolution of about 0.04 cm-1.  While adequate for lighter molecules (such as CuO, GeH), having similar Doppler line width, superior resolution was required for 5d transition metals, many with multiple isotopes.  As part of this grant, we successfully integrated our intracavity laser spectrometer with a Fourier transform detection system (i.e., ILS-FTS).  Compared with traditional ILS, the new ILS-FTS system provides several advantages including increased spectral coverage per spectrum limited by the ILS laser profile (about 50 cm-1 vs. 5 cm-1 for traditional ILS), smaller resolution element, and more accurate frequency calibration.  The ILS-FTS system has enhanced our capabilities for fundamental research in spectroscopy; a schematic is provided in Figure 1.

The ILS-FTS method led to an enormous improvement in that isotopic features are now fully or partially resolved even for a (0,0) vibrational band.  Figure 2 shows a portion of the (0,0) band of the A Ω=1 ‒ X Ω=0+ transition of PtS, where the black spectrum is the original ILS configuration, and the red spectrum is the ILS-FTS spectrum with enhanced spectral resolution.  Isotopologue structure of PtS is clearly resolved in the red trace.

Graduate student Kristin Bales completed a study on ILS-FTS equivalent pathlengths and generation time settings. She found that molecular absorbance did not correlate with generation time as expected.  This implies the data acquisition timing of the Bruker IFS FTS is not as described in the FTS user's manual.  This finding does not affect our ability to obtain high quality data ? a summation of signals over the complete integration time is observed rather than one at the specific generation time set by the AOM.

2.      Molecular Radicals Investigated.  We recorded and analyzed spectra of NiF, GeH, PtF, PtCl, CuOH, CuOD, CuO, PtS, TaF, and WS.  Twelve peer-reviewed papers from our research appeared in the Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy (x9), the Journal of Chemical Physics (x2), and the Journal of Molecular Structure (x1).  Some projects are described below.

PtF.  Using the ILS-FTS approach, spectra of several electronic transitions of PtF were obtained.  The PtF isotopologue structure (e.g., 194PtF, 195PtF, and 196PtF) is clearly resolved as shown in Figure 3.  Enhanced analysis (mass-independent Dunham fit with electronic field-shift effects) led to interesting results.  The field shift constants allow comparison with high level ab initio calculations that include multi-configurational excited electronic states and electron densities at the nucleus.

CuOH and CuOD.  As shown in Figure 4, we recorded ILS spectra several electronic transitions of CuOH and CuOD.  Although the bandhead positions of these transitions were previously reported, two had eluded spectral analysis until our work.

PtS.  We analyzed several electronic transitions of PtS.  Nine vibrational bands of the [15.9] B Ω=0+ ‒ X 3Σ‒ Ω=0+ transition were identified.  The A Ω=1 ‒ X 3Σ‒ Ω=0+ transition also was recorded and analyzed.  This PtS transition was particularly interesting as the Q-branch was perturbed.  Additionally, hyperfine structure was observed for 195PtS in the Q-branch only (see Figure 5).  Through careful examination, we concluded that an Ω=0‒ state was perturbing the [15.9] B Ω=0+ state, and a deperturbation analysis was performed.

3.      Work Force Development.  Our work has strengthened a successful inter-institutional collaboration of faculty and students, and further developed skills of all participants in spectroscopy, interpretation of molecular constants, and instrument development.  Because FTS is now utilized in many facets of instrumental analysis, we saw an increase in student participation in research programs at both locations: seven graduate students and five undergraduate students have worked on these projects, participating in every aspect of the work.  Additionally, since Summer 2016 we mentored eight gifted high school students associated with the St. Louis area STARS program, which offered a well-organized summer research experience.  Eleven of our twelve publications include at least one student co-author.  Of the 20 participants (2 PIs, 7 grad students, 5 undergrad students, and 8 high school students), 7 were women and 3 were underrepresented minority students.
